question: What's that?
answer: We walk past this temple every day, Karen --

question: Yeah, but I've never seen this before. It's a Buddhist ritual. The incense smoke carries the prayers to the spirits of his ancestors, to help them remain at peace.
answer: It's amazing. You're like this infinite storehouse of wisdom. Or trivia. I'm not sure which.

question: It's not trivia. It's what they believe. And it's far better, by the way, than your little pollution ritual. What?
answer: Nothing. I just -- I like that about you. You seem to be able to remember everything that's really important. Except the time.

question: Oh, crap -- C'mon, you're gonna be late. Uh-uh. Seven years of bad luck. And I might have a vested interest in those years.
answer: Is that right?

question: Maybe.
answer: Will I see you tonight?

question: I'll call you when I get home.
answer: Fourteen. I hate odd numbers.

question: Karen! Are you free this afternoon?
answer: I just came by to pick up some books I left here. I'm not scheduled to work today --

question: I know. But are you free? Do you have class?
answer: Just a test to study for. Why?

question: Your wish has been granted. It's Yoko's case, but she didn't show up for work this morning, and I can't reach her at home. She must be sick, or something. And she has the damn house key.
answer: What's this phrase?

question: You're up?
answer: Mmmmmm.

question: I wonder if Mom's okay. She's been sleeping ever since we got here.
answer: Not at night. I told you, Matthew, you can sleep through anything.

question: I'm sorry, sweetheart. It was probably just the move -- I'm sure she'll get back on schedule. You seen my travel mug?
answer: I didn't unpack it yet.

question: Maybe you should say something to the helper, what's her name?
answer: Yoko.

question: Who knows? Maybe there's something she can suggest.
answer: Yeah. Maybe.

question: I miss seeing this every morning. No response from his wife. He turns to see Jennifer looking down at Emma through the window. Hey, kiddo. You okay?
answer: I went for a walk yesterday. Just to explore. I got lost and couldn't find anyone who could speak English, who could help me. I felt so... stupid.

question: This will get easier soon, for Mom, for all of us. I promise.
answer: Or else?

question: Or else I'll tell the company it's just not working out, and that we're going back to the States with or without my old job. They can get someone else to crunch their numbers. But until then -- promise me you'll give it a good try, okay Jen?
answer: Deal.

question: Is this Yoko's bike?
answer: I think so.

question: It's been here all night. I'll probably be home late, maybe around nine or so.
answer: I knew you'd forget. Dinner, your sister? At seven?

question: Oh yeah. Right.
answer: You were going to cook.

question: I have a big conference. They usually run long.
answer: I'll do the shopping. Just call me if you're going to be late. If you need something, all you have to do is say so -- Who's -- who's there?

question: Sorry I'm late, it took awhile to wrap things up. Jen? Susan? What the hell? -- Mom? Are you alright? Where's Jennifer, Mom? Did Yoko come today, Mom? Remember? The pretty girl? Jen? Are you up there? Dammit. Jennifer? What is it -- What's wrong? What happened??? I'll... I'll call an ambulance... Dammit! Jesus Christ... `Ambulance'... "kyukyusha". Who are you? What -- what are you doing here?
answer: Hello? You guys in the kitchen? I thought you guys were gonna cook! Hi, Mom. How are you feeling? I guess I came at a bad time, huh? I'll give you guys one minute to finish whatever you're doing up there and get your butts down here. I mean it, guys. Well, I warned you. Prepare to be emotionally scarred. Matthew! Don't scare me like that! What's going on? Where's Jennifer?

question: She went out. Something came up.
answer: I hope she's not long. I'm absolutely starving. I knew it. You guys forgot to go shopping, didn't you?

question: I'm sorry. This is a bad time.
answer: Are you okay? What's going on?

question: You should go.
answer: Did something happen? What's --

question: She doesn't love me... she never loved me...
answer: What are you talking about? Stop it, Matthew.

question: Leave me alone.
answer: Matthew, please --

question: GO AWAY!!!
answer: This is Suzuki-san, he's the Real Estate broker.

question: What did he say?
answer: He said Your shoes.

question: Where's Mom?
answer: Mom? Where are you?

question: Did you get her?
answer: Take a pill, will ya? C'mon, Mom. You know what the doctor said about stairs.

question: She okay?
answer: Mom? What is it?

question: It's perfect. We'll take it.
answer: Hey, guys, it's Susan. Matt, are you there? Pick up... Okay, well, I'm leaving work now so you can try my cell, or just call me at home later. I just wanted to make sure Mom is okay. Yesterday was... Is anybody there? In the stairs... there was... something... a strange person... all the lights were going out... Please. Help me.

question: Hello?
answer: It's me.

question: Matthew! Are you alright?
answer: I'm downstairs. What number are you again?

question: I am Detective Nakagawa. This is Detective Igarashi, my assistant.
answer: Is Karen okay?

question: She is very shaken. We would like her to stay in the hospital tonight, under evaluation. Do you know these people?
answer: Matthew Williams, and his wife Jennifer. He's Emma's son, the woman Karen came here to see.

question: When was the last time you saw him?
answer: I met them when they came to register. It's standard procedure, though the visits were arranged by his employer. He works at --

question: We've spoken with his employer. He did not show up for work today. If you could please come by tomorrow to make a statement, the address is there, at the bottom --
answer: Yoko.

question: I'm sorry?
answer: Karen was a substitute -- Yoko is the girl who is normally in charge of Emma. She's also been missing from work.

question: For how long?
answer: For the last two days. I think I saw her bike outside.

question: Who does this belong to?
answer: We don't know.

question: I can use the blood to help identify the person.
answer: Is it possible that someone could live without... that?

question: It's okay. I've got you. Your boss told me what happened. I'm sorry. I talked to your teachers. They said you can take as much time as you need. We could go to Kyoto for a weekend, see those temples you're always talking about.
answer: Running away won't help.

question: There's nothing to run away from, Kat. No one blames you for what happened.
answer: I'm not even sure what did happen.

question: You went to help someone who was, quite simply, beyond help.
answer: No, that's not what I mean... That house. There was something...

question: Don't beat yourself up searching for a greater truth, Kat. An old woman passed away in her sleep. It's sad, but that's all it is --
answer: Is that how they said she died?

question: I'm sorry this happened to you. But maybe, in a way, it will help you later. Death is an unfortunate but integral part of your future career. There's no avoiding it. Maybe now you'll be more... ready for it.
answer: I don't think I'll ever be ready for something like that.

question: Why don't you find out when I can check out of here.
answer: How are you feeling?

question: Okay. Tired.
answer: You are an exchange student? And you have been volunteering at the Health Center for...?

question: Three months. I needed a social welfare credit.
answer: You said this was the first time you'd been in that house?

question: Yes.
answer: About the Japanese boy you said you saw there --

question: Did you find him?
answer: No, not yet. You said the boy had been taped into the closet?

question: Yes, that's right. He was... holding a cat. A black cat. There was a book in the closet, too. I think it was a journal.
answer: Did it belong to the boy?

question: I don't think so. I think it belonged to a woman. The writing. It looked feminine. I left it on the kitchen table.
answer: I didn't see any book on the table. Perhaps someone moved it. Did you speak with the boy after you opened the closet?

question: I asked him his name. He said `Toshio'.
answer: One more question, please. We found this in the room where...

question: This is him. This is the boy.
answer: Are you certain?

question: Yes. Positive. Detective Nakagawa? The whole time I was in that house, I felt something was... wrong. What happened there?
answer: The bodies of the son and daughter- in-law of the woman you were caring for were found in the attic. It seems that the son killed his wife, and then himself -- Please excuse me for a moment.

question: The bodies of the son and daughter- in-law of the woman you were caring for were found in the attic. It seems that the son killed his wife, and then himself -- Please excuse me for a moment.
answer: We checked the apartment of Susan, the sister. She wasn't there...

question: Yes?
answer: The chain lock had been drawn from the inside. And the deadbolt. But we found no one in the apartment.

question: Get the surveillance tapes from the office building.
answer: They were the first family to live in that house since the incident three years ago --

question: Then how did she get from the house to the Health Center?
answer: I have no idea.

question: She survived for two days without this?
answer: It would seem so.

question: How is that possible?
answer: I don't believe it is.

question: I got us a guidebook to Kyoto. I thought maybe we'd leave tomorrow --
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: Tell you what?
answer: About the bodies they found in the attic.

question: You were recovering from a shock. I didn't want to -- Karen -- wait -- Look, I'm sorry. I was just worried about you, and -- I know you, Karen.
answer: The same thing happened three years ago, Doug. To a Japanese family, who lived in that house. They were all found dead.

question: So you think the events are connected?
answer: How would you explain it?

question: Okay. How about this It's exactly how superstitions survive
answer: -- trip over the curb and sprain your ankle.

question: Makes sense, right?
answer: Okay. Then explain this

question: Saw what? Karen?
answer: Emma and I were alone in that room, but -- there was something else there. I'm sure of it.

question: You watched a woman die, Kat. That's a horrible thing to experience. I can't imagine how you must feel. But sometimes the mind tries to cope with terrible things in a way that distorts what actually occurred.
answer: You might be right, Doug. But I know what I saw. I think I know what I saw...

question: You just need to rest. We'll get you home, get a good night's sleep.
answer: Yeah. You've got class, and I'm sure I only have to fill out a few forms or something --

question: You sure?
answer: I'm fine, Doug. Really.

question: I come bearing gifts.
answer: That's the boy who was there yesterday. In that house. But this boy, he's -- -- he's supposed to be dead. I saw him, Doug. I talked to him. He told me his name. A boy who was killed by his father three years ago told me his name. You don't believe me.

question: How can I believe you, Karen?
answer: Hello? What? Alex and Yoko are dead. There's something wrong with that house, Doug. Something really bad. The boy in that house, he had a photo of this man. He died on that same day three years ago. I need to talk to his wife... widow. If I can find out what happened, or if... maybe --

question: Maybe, what? I'm concerned about you going out while you're so upset --
answer: You don't understand. I have to, Doug.

question: Why?
answer: Because I've been inside that house, Doug. Don't you get it? I've been inside! I love you. But I have to go. I'm looking for Maria Kirk?

question: Because I've been inside that house, Doug. Don't you get it? I've been inside! I love you. But I have to go. I'm looking for Maria Kirk?
answer: Who is this?

question: My name is Karen Davies. I'm a student at -- I'm sorry to bother you, but I was wondering if I could ask you a few questions. Ms. Kirk?
answer: Questions about what?

question: I'm here because... I need to speak with you about your husband.
answer: Leave me alone.

question: Maria --
answer: Please. I'm late for work.

question: I just need a couple minutes.
answer: Make yourself at home. Well?

question: Your husband, Peter. Three years ago he...
answer: He what?

question: He killed himself. I'm... sorry.
answer: Thank you. How did you know Peter?

question: I didn't.
answer: Then what are you doing here?

question: I think there's a connection between your husband's death and something that happened to me.
answer: What happened to you?

question: It's... hard to explain. Look, I know this sounds strange, but... I don't think your husband wanted to die.
answer: Then why would he throw himself out a window? Let me guess I put all this behind me. I don't want to open it back up again.

question: If that's true, then why are you still here in Japan?
answer: Because I can't leave. I tried. But I couldn't. Not without... He usually didn't wake up before me. But that morning, he did. He made coffee for us. Then he sat there and waited for me to wake up. And when I did, he looked me right in the eye. And then he jumped. The night before we'd been talking about having children together...

question: Did you know a woman named Kayako?
answer: No.

question: Did Peter?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Maybe it was someone he worked with?
answer: Look. I've had the police up here, I talked with Detectives, I even hired a P.I.--

question: Please. I don't know what else to do. Please help me.
answer: This is all his stuff from school. This was our first date.

question: Oh my God.
answer: What? Did you find something?
